review_title: Great place to work, competitive salary is not a priority!
pros: NC State has great benefits, and is very flexible, depending on your department and duties. It's overall been a great place to work, though advancement has been a challenge.
cons: This is a place of silos, one department or college may have way more resources than the one in which you are working, which means difference in salaries, job titles, duties and what you're allowed to do. You are greatly limited by your department's budget - and they're not all equal. Raises and bonuses, are practically non-existent, and in order to advance, you often have to leave the university and come back years later. Not an environment where "working your way up" works as it should. Often, you're working your way out - over to another university, and then maybe years later back into a higher position. Hiring takes forever in some departments.

pros: The overall culture and work environment is great!

Interacting with and supporting PI's performing research at the cutting edge of their respective disciplines pushes the limits of your knowledge and fosters growth. I find that the diversity of the campus population academically, ethnically, internationally, racially, and spiritually, has fostered my understanding, acceptance and connection with people different yet not so different from me and offered additional opportunities for personal growth. In addition, the benefits of working on an academic campus include an employee degree program and access to all of the excellent library and recreation facilities.
cons: Very few downsides. Wage growth may not always keep up with industry, but the shakeup caused by COVID has moved the needle in better aligning compensation in order to stay competitive in hiring.

Staff is generally overworked and well underpaid...we're talking super motivated and exceptional people with Masters degrees making $40-50,000. Leadership doesn't seem to understand the shift in generations occurring in the workplace dictates a change in management philosophies and strategy.

review_title: A great university until it became “woke”
pros: Used to be a great university with great leadership, faculty, staff and students.
cons: University leaders and deans are obsessed with race. We receive multiple emails per day reminding everyone of “white privilege” (which is not a thing). Each time a news event occurs it is politicized by the Chancellor and Deans (George Floyd trial was inappropriately noted as a racial crime, despite no evidence of such, and leaders took the position of celebrating a guilty verdict for the officer involved). The university actually has a policy that prohibits employees from engaging in political activities while at work (it’s a fireable offense), yet the institution’s leaders literally do it everyday. Extremely left-winged leadership has ruined the university for the reasonable people that work there.

review_title: Graduate research is not standardized at all.
pros:
My work life is largely dependent on my PI's whims or ideas. Sometimes he leads me in the right direction or I spend a few months going around in circles. I can show up and leave whenever I feel like as long as my PI likes me and thinks I'm working hard. 
I can employ undergrads as free labor and they can make it look like I'm working very hard. You can drop a Ph.D. program after 3 years and essentially be handed a paid M.Sc..
cons:
Work can be very monotonous and completely useless. Your PI may decide what you'll do for the next 5 years whether you like the subject or not. 3 years in he could change it because it's not working out and put you on something better or worse. You could be stuck learning a technique that is no longer relevant to the world or doing research that will never be read. 
Personally, I found the post-doc intolerable. My work was dictated by this person because my PI is never around (I meet with the PI once every couple of weeks or so). I've been slapped and berated by the post-doc to the point where I don't feel as confident as when I started. 
If your PI lost funding, don't plan on going to any conferences or doing research that requires funding. This can a huge problem if you're planning on networking or getting a job after graduating.

review_title: Applying to be an RA? Think again...
pros:
- great team (other RAs) to work with
 - conflict management experience
 - good if you like interacting with individuals
cons:
- poor response to COVID-19 (paid approx. $4 an hour for 20 hours a week of work)
- upper management is unresponsive to feedback (sometimes our feedback doesn't even get that far up there)
 - unorganized (were going through a "transition" period that seemed neverending)
 - empty promises made

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this position to anyone. On the surface, the benefits look good (free housing and meal plan + stipend), but you need to understand that RAs are SO replaceable. We do so much in the residence halls that upper management can't even begin to understand, but you could disagree with the way they do things (COVID-19 response, program planning/Packchat requirements) and they won't care because there are hundreds of other students lined up for the exact same job. You are replaceable and they will not listen to your feedback and strive for change as they should.

Bottom line is, they may seem like they welcome your feedback and have an "open door policy" but nothing will get done, so don't get your hopes up.

pros:
Free room and board and great meal plan coverage. The stipend is also fairly generous, with a convenient bi-weekly direct deposit plan. 

Depending on which Residence Hall and section of campus you are assigned, you may have an easy time and meet lots of great people and get valuable leadership experience.

In addition, you really get connected to the majority of resources on campus because you must know about them.

You get 12 days off a semester as well.
cons:
The duties of the RA at NC State are not entirely time-sucking nor frequent, however recently new changes to policies have cropped up under the "Duties as assigned" clause in the job description.

As of now, interactions with residents are recorded and given to upper administration for their personal use -- which is largely undefined. This is my least favorite part of the job because I feel like I am secretly breaking the trust of residents and sharing personal information that was never intended to be public. It is downright creepy and honestly makes me seek out less personal relationships with residents because of my guilt.

Also, on a lighter note, you get to watch University throw large amounts of money into "enrichment programs" that maybe ten people show up to. Some events are decent and informative, but they are almost all highly repetitious and predictable and avoided by residents.

review_title: NCSU is an awesome place to work
pros: There are great health and dental benefits  which are the same for all state employees. There is also the opportunity to take classes at any of the state supported schools  (UNC, ECU, etc) for very little (about $10 per credit hour). Its a very good working environment, with lots of room for advancement and lateral movement. Because it's primary function is education, new ideas are always accepted and encouraged. The department I'm most familiar with has also emphasizes the development of younger staff, and this has created a great deal of respect for the school and appreciation among these staff members.
cons: The HR departments in some divisions is a bit slow to get information out to employees, thought the main HR office is pretty good. Also, as an employee of the state, but working at NCSU, sometimes the vacation times do not line up, so employees working at the university are required to take vacation days at these times; the university is closed, but the state doesnt have an official holiday. There is the pay for parking issue (employees still have to buy a parking permit) but its worse at some other area schools so I guess it isnt that big of a problem.

review_title: NC State University - on the rise
pros: NC State has long been one of the best values in public education and in many areas the quality of education and the rankings of the programs are increasing rapidly. For example, the MBA program is now one of the top 20 programs if you are focusing on management of technology companies or innovation and entrepreneurship. Many of the engineering programs are top notch, especially when it comes to engaging students in applied research at all levels. There is a big emphases on practical work, which means companies love to hire NC State alum.
cons: The university still has some negative legacy issues. While parts of the university are innovative, there are still many parts that are doing things the old way because that's the way it has always been done. Legacy systems, especially in the financial inner-workings of the university need adapting to the new global world.

review_title: Good for a job, not a career
pros: Laid back environment.  Free classes.  good benefits.  NCSU has a good culture with lots to do in the nearby area and employees get perks like discounted tickets.  If you like college football, staff can get tickets to many of the home games.
cons:
Slow and limited upward mobility.  It is difficult to 'make your mark'.  Being excellent at your job is almost irrelevant in terms of compensation or promotion.  In many cases, NCSU will employ you in a 'Job', but not a 'career'.  Most people either leave quickly to advance or stick around forever because their skills are very specific to the university and they are not competitive in the outside environment.  

Units in the university often have difficulty communicating and due to the nature of the organization, little clear direction other than 'do what you did yesterday'.

review_title: The crop science department is awesome!
job_title: Student Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: I come from an animal background and as an undergraduate decided to get a job working in the crop science department as a student worker.  I have expanded my knowledge of plants and broadened my knowledge of research protocol and contacts within the crop science department.  You will always learn at North Caroline State no matter what you are doing; the opportunities are always there!
cons: The graduate students I work with are going non-stop and I sometimes feel obligated to give them more of my time rather than keeping it to myself and leaving and going home.  That obligation has also kept me from going out-of-town, except for July 4th.

pros: If you are one of the better colleges, e.g. engineering, then conditions are fairly good given that you are in a second tier University.  Teaching loads etc. are consistent with most peers.  Frankly, many faculty stay here because the quality of life is so good.  The climate is moderate, costs are around the national average, its not a University only town, etc.
cons: Funding per unit is lower here than at most peers.  After you go through your startup package, you are completely on your own in terms of buying equipment, starting new efforts etc. in Enginneering there is little or no overhead return (currently none).   You even (usually) have to come up with the funds if you want to patent something.  In 2014, after 5 years of almost zero raises and regular cuts, adminsitrative support is overstretched and teaching assistants have all but disappeared.

pros: Until recently the benefits.  The mandatory (TERS and ORP) pension plans are great.  Generally speaking, the office environment gentle.  You leave work at work.  Decent tuition-wavier plan.  Great vacation and sick time package.
cons: The health insurance (even the 80/20 plan) has high deductibles.  The compensation is low.  In the private sector, someone with my skill set would receive close to $65K-$70K a year.  While office environment is gentle, the agenda of the university as whole is liberal/socialist.  Promotion is difficult.  Its not what you know but who you are connected to politically.  Raises are unheard of unless you are faculty.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: The university in general has a good engineering program and some engineering tracks are among the top 10 in the nation. The engineering campus is growing fast and recently opened one of the most high-tech libraries in the nation. The university also hosts two NSF ERCs and will host a new innovation technology center in wide band-gap power electronics and power semiconductor technology. Thus, there are plenty of research opportunities in general, and especially in electrical engineering, materials engineering and so on.
cons: Although ECE department has the highest number of students among of engineering departments, it has the lowest base salary for teaching and research assistant positions which has not changed over the years. The state has been suffering from a budget deficit which has strongly affected the economy of university and graduate student support plan. The student fee has been growing steadily over the past years and they have one of the highest fees.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Collaborative and supportive graduate student environment.
Lots of opportunities to gain teaching experience after preliminary semester of lecture assistantship or recitation leadership. 
Teach only 1 class per semester.
Good health insurance.
NC State grad students typically have good job prospects because of experience.
The department is actively recruiting stellar young professors as several faculty are in the process of retiring.
1+ REG opportunities with travel funding available for early career graduate students.
Primary Instructors have full responsibilities.
cons:
The department's budget, like most state schools, it at the mercy of the state budget.
The teaching observation and advising system is not well-enforced and faculty often show up only once in a semester and rarely check-in with TA instructors.
Very few courses are actually "coordinated" by the assigned faculty member.

review_title: Research Associate -  Dept of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering
pros:
A lot of top-notch research is done in the Department, so research opportunities abound.
Potential to be mentored by top scientists in a field, but choose wisely!
Same insurance benefits as students (fantastic if you have a family)
cons:
Financial compensation will be much lower than you could find elsewhere (that's to be expected though).
Ability to use this experience to get your next job depends entirely on whether you can push out papers and keep a good relationship with your advisor.  Conflict with your advisor could be disastrous since (s)he is the only one someone can call later for a reference.

review_title: Great Co-Workers, Good flexibility & Vacation - Lower Pay
job_title: Academic Affairs Coordinator in Raleigh, NC
pros: My experience has been really great overall! I have educated, thoughtful co-workers and a boss that trusts me to get my work completed well - without any micromanagement. I have a lot of personal flexibility, a ton (nearly 5 weeks) of vacation, plus sick leave and holidays; so the work-life balance is pretty good, which is really important!
cons: Salary. My salary isn't competitive with what I could be making in industry - it's not even close and because you're a state employee raises are largely based on the state legislature's budget and that is typically a 0.5% to 1.5% raise per year (if the economy is good).

review_title: Good Job, LOW PAY, Fam. Cvg. HLTH Ins. is 600 per month,  No Raise in 4 years
pros: Pension, job security, workload, job stress is low, scenery.
cons: LOW LOW PAY.  Expect to make on average 15 to 20% below what you could elsewhere.  Health Insurance is almost 600 per month for 70/30 family coverage in 2011.  No raise in 3 and 1/2 years.  You have to be able to play the game or you will drive yourself crazy trying to make things right.

review_title: Overall positive but has it's ups and downs.
pros:
There are opportunities to work with leaders in research and to teach / mentor students and see them develop beyond the walls of the classroom.
Individual departments (such as mine) and individual supervisors (such as mine) can be very proactive in managing increasingly diminishing budgets in order to keep staff employed.  This can also be a negative if your supervisor is not so inclined or does not have the financial resources.
cons:
Research staff are at the bottom of the feeding pool in the overall university mission as faculty and students must come first.
Health benefits have been declining over the years.
Staff salaries are low; somewhat managable in the RDU area but difficult to save money if you have a family.
Vacation benefits are very good.

review_title: A great place for the right, motivated individual. The sky is the limit...just stay motivated.
pros: You can do great things; anything you want, if you are motivated. Staying motivated is difficult because there are a lot of people who, more or less, are just biding their time. That attitude can be contagious.
cons: The pay, which is no real fault of a department. Generally, departments across campus vary. The faculty and staff are great. The administration is weak and virtually impotent at driving anything. From my observations, this applies from the Vice Chancellor on up to the Chancellor level.

review_title: Frustrated by the lack of honest communication from leadership
pros: It is exciting to be part of a community where amazing research takes place.  Some of our scientists are incredibly dedicated and share their excitement with students.
cons: Leadership does not provide honest communication regarding significant organizational changes.  Change is very slow and gets bogged down in numerous committees.  Succession planning is almost nonexistent in most parts of the organization.  No raises for most employees thanks to state budget cuts and benefits have been reduced.  However, even when we did get raises there was no difference in what a high performer receives and what a poor performer receives.

review_title: A good place to be a civil servant
job_title: Director of Educational Technology in Raleigh, NC
pros: NC State has heart. We do great things for tomorrow's leaders, and we do them well. I'm lucky in that I started here young and have had ample growth opportunity. I'm not sure the situation is as good people who tend to job hop a lot.
cons: Mostly compensation. When I started here, below average salaries were balanced by the academic environment, however, more and more this place becomes like a business, except for the salary part. I will say that if you manage to stick it out for the full 30, the retirement compensation is pretty darn decent.

pros: There is tremendous engineering activity and many exciting projects in all fields of engineering.
cons: Working in a State Government organization can be frustrating as there are significant delays waiting for non-essential personnel to do their jobs which are not always necessary, but are University policies and are paid in part from the overhead levied on research projects.

review_title: I was very impressed with the people and felt very accepted and got all of the help that I needed.
pros: Great co-workers, everyone always willing to help, great work environment, great communication amongst veterinary techinicians, a lot of flexibility, plenty of room for advancement
cons: very hectic and busy for someone like me (great for people that like that kind of thing), don't get to interact a lot with the supervisors (they are mostly office workers)

review_title: My career reached a high peak of development at NCSU
pros: The intellectual  environment at NCSU is generally positive  because a large fraction of Faculty salaries is "hard " money. As a result there is sufficient stability for the development and attainment of long term intellectual, scholarly goals.
cons: The direct interface between Departmental Faculty  and Deans/Directors is not strong enough. There is the appearance, if not the fact(!),  of  "top down" management  by the Administration to the Faculty and Departments, even though significant funds for research required to maintain advanced scholarly programs  are developed by Faculty members themselves.

pros: You get to set your work hours around your class schedule. You work with student athletes and help them study. A very good job if you are interested in teaching.
cons: The athletes sometimes want you to do their homework for them and the staff doesn't seem to care much about the athletes' academic career as long as they stay eligible.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Everything has been on my times. I have been able to work when I am able and can choose not to work when I am really busy. This is a very good opportunity for the college students that have busy and varying schedules.
cons: So I've been working for over 6 weeks now and I still haven't been put in the system for pay yet. There has been nothing more frustrating than this because I don't know what caused the hold up. My advisers continuously fought for it, but the system was moving very slowly.

review_title: Good work environment, benefits leave a lot to be desired
pros: The work environment is quite good, professors are free to pursue their own interests. Work hours for faculty are flexible. The department has good administrative support.
cons: The benefits package is not very competitive. Salary raises depend strongly on the state economy. Student enrollments in graduate level courses are insane -- 80 to 100 students per section are nit unusual. Often, raises and other benefits are not based strictly on merit.

review_title: Very overall positive experience as a graduate student in toxicology program
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: The training in the toxicology department has been comprehensive.  I have been happy in my lab and feel that I have learned a great deal of techniques that will help me in the future.  The professors are great and helpful and overall I'm very happy to come to work every day.  I don't feel as if the department is super competitive and I have a nice work-life balance.
cons: Department politics can affect your experience in the program and/or your lab.  Before the Toxicology department was merged in the large Department of Biological Sciences, things were great, but the recent merger has brought many changes and eliminated the small, intimate feel, which is unfortunate.

job_title: Career Services Coordinator in Raleigh, NC
pros: The student population is really great to work with compared to some other schools. The administration is pretty reasonable. Most co-workers are very friendly. Benefits are State of NC benefits and are pretty good. Plus, there's a lot of annual leave days and a pretty decent retirement plan. Communication from leadership is pretty open.
cons: Depending on your department, you may or may not get much onboarding, though the onboarding process for the university as a whole is fantastic. There's never enough money to do what you want to do, but people are pretty resourceful about figuring out new ways to manage.

review_title: Great school to perform research and be connected to local businesses.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Depending on the which department and research group you join, there are some research groups which are equipped and the researcher can carry out descent research. There is a modern, quite brand new library on Centennial campus and great gym on the main campus.
cons: The university dinning place on the Centennial campus does not serve food with high variety and high quality, apposed to dinning rooms on the main campus. Moreover, some departments require the graduate students pay high fees to the Engineering school.

review_title: NCSU is a good choice if you are considering graduate school
pros:
Good collaboration between departments,  sharing of knowledge and resources.
Well qualified faculty and extremely supportive of students. All graduate students in the Biochemistry department are completely funded and have minimum teaching requirements which allows more time for research work.
cons: Certain facilities are not  easily accessible to everyone. Budget deficit had led to shutting down of certain campus facilities and laying off of lab personnel and other administrative staff.  Departmental budgets have reduced and has affected the class room size, number of courses offered and recruiting new students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great to be a grad student in the Plant Pathology department at NCSU, but CALS is going through a lot of changes now which makes the day-to-day workings of most departments more difficult.
cons: Outrageous spending on administration has contributed to skyrocketing costs of tuition and student fees, which is something to consider if you are funding students through your own secured grants as a faculty or you are paying your own way as a graduate student without an assistantship.

job_title: Technology Support Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: My office always had a very positive work environment, and I really enjoyed my supervisor. NC State did a great job of facilitating an inclusive work atmosphere that never made me hate coming to work.
cons: In my specific department that I worked with, the leadership in one of the departments we were closely associated with ended up being fairly political and at times downright petty. While workplace politics are always present, I thought this instance was out of place and excessive.

pros: The work environment is quite good, professors are free to pursue their own interests. Work hours for faculty are flexible. The department has good administrative support.
cons: The benefits package is not very competitive. Salary raises depend strongly on the state economy. Student enrollments in graduate level courses are insane -- 80 to 100 students per section are nit unusual. Often, raises and other benefits are not based strictly on merit.

pros: If you're lazy and have no scruples you can work here. I'm resigning and am so happy to be done with the drama.
cons: Management is awful, they hire people with no supervisory experience. People are lazy to the point of actually sleeping on the job and getting away with it. No merit raises, you're at the mercy of the legislature, and the most you get is only 2%. That's across the board, so if you do your job well you only get the same as the sleeper. The office itself is rundown and in an unsafe neighborhood. The supervisor is an airhead who has no clue about leadership. Most of my co-workers spend their days gossiping about whatever.

review_title: Teaching Assistant with College of Natural Resources
pros: I worked as an undergraduate TA for 5 class sessions. Senior Seminar in Environmental Technology, Intro to Photovoltaics, Environmental Science 100, and Issues in Water Quality. Pay was good for college level employment and my work hours were flexible. Highly recommend a job like this for undergraduates looking to learn more and boost long term employ-ability. Be forward and ask Professors for available assistance ships as they often are not advertised.
cons: Sometimes direction was vague at best. Be prepared to encounter some situations where you must plan and teach lab sessions at your own discretion. If you are prepared for it, you can teach some great sessions!

review_title: Excellent College of Vet Med and great people
job_title: Operations Research Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros: Got to work with some amazing individuals in various levels, from Doctors and instructors, to lab assistants and those who worked behind the scenes.
cons: Sometimes seems to be more interested in funding than teaching. We need people who can teach AND people that can bring in research money, sometimes, it is hard to find those that can do both. We need Teaching focused positions to graduate well-rounded, prepared doctors

review_title: Every year was worse than the last one.
pros: Ill admit the benefits package for faculty was solid.  Great retirement options, flex accounts, and lots of institutional discounts were nothing to sneeze at although they were outshined by peer instutions.
cons: The community is a very self-congratulatory one that often sees its own progress outside of any comparative context.  So that a movement forward for them is still light years behind other places.   They heavily recruited me for the faculty, but as soon as I joined the tune changed pretty drastically.  Not much was as it has been described and I felt duped and trapped.

review_title: Worked as a graduate research assistant while pursuing my PhD
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: NCSU is a great school. The facilities are state of the art and the opportunities to learn and further your education make graduate school a great investment of your time.
cons: The biggest hindrances to quality research at this university are the incompetent tech transfer office and a very slow IRB review board. Iv'e had to write several of my patents myself because the Tech transfer office was not able to meet deadlines or keep up with filing paperwork on time. I've had many offers to license several of my patents and the university's tech trans office can't seem to follow up with anything.

review_title: Working for NC State can be very different depending on which college/department you work in.
pros: Benefits are good if you started working for the State of North Carolina before 2003. Pretty good job security. Each office/department/college is different so do not assume any stated about one area of campus will be true for all areas of campus.
cons: The current state government does not value state employment as a whole so we have not received a noticeable pay raise in 7 years.  The current state government also has cut funding for higher education each year they have been in office, and plan to do so again in the next year's budget.

review_title: Outstanding supportive working environment, educational culture values creativity
job_title: Associate Director Sponsored Programs in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Professional treatment of staff in support of faculty. Recognition of accomplishments.
Opportunities for advancement in several specialties of administration.  Location is excellent in a dynamic culturally diverse community that is growing and active.  Excellent public school system so far.
cons: Compensation tied to state government, which provides little stability or independence regardless of contribution to the overall mission.  State government does not appreciate the value of investing in education at any level. Reductions in support are masked by political claims and grandstanding while the youth suffer a more demanding job market.

review_title: Getting paid while pursuing a doctorate
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Salary provides a level of flexibility due to cheap living conditions in the Raleigh area. Depending on professor, the hours required vs. efficiency of progress towards a doctorate can allow for a manageable work/life balance. I chose correctly.
cons: As a graduate student you are compensated for "half time" (ie 20 hours per week) but expected to work whatever it takes to get the job done (dependent on professor's expectations).

review_title: Always provides good opportunities for growth
pros: Makes sure that student workers don't overwork themselves while in school by limiting graduate students to 29 hours of work per week or less. Cares about its workers, and provides an encouraging work environment.
cons: I can sometimes feel I'm lost in the organization because NCSU is so big and has so many employees. But my immediate supervisors make up for that by having bi-weekly inclusive meetings, and check in on a regular basis.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: As a whole, I would say that people are friendlier and more professional at NCSU compared to other universities with similar levels of academic quality. They also focus more on getting to students the skills and opportunities they need to get hired in industry.
cons: Depending on the graduate department and committee, the coursework and networking opportunities available may be less focused on preparing students to land academic positions compared to those available at similar universities. However, as stated, not all programs fit that general trend. Moreover, the emphasis on academia relative to industry at NCSU is only noticeably, not grossly, different.

review_title: NCSU math Ph.D. and teaching assistantship
job_title: Math Ph D Student and Teaching Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Very supportive faculty. Many Ph.D. progams expect students to conform to the research goals of the faculty members, but at NCSU math, they are very supportive of the students and the student's interests. Most classes are taught by faculty who enjoy teaching graduate students and at good at what they do.
There are many opportunities to teach as well if that is desired.
cons: Lower TA salary than in math departments at other schools ($18,000/yr as of 2019), and lately the department is low on funding, so TAs are expected to do more work than in the past with no raise in several years.

review_title: Best on campus part time job
pros: I joined Campus housing in 2007 and did not know what to expect being my first part time job. Well the two and  a half years at Campus housing were the best part of my stay at NC State. I would recommend people to take up campus housing job at any  day.
cons: Please be prepared to work the early morning jobs if you do not life to stay up late !

review_title: My experience has been positive.  I've gained a great deal of knowledge and cutting-edge research experience.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scholar in Raleigh, NC
pros: There are significant resources and facilities to support investigators research activities.  The faculty are world-renowned in their respective areas of research and are very supportive in mentoring junior investigators.
cons: The salary for individuals in training (i.e. postdocs) is not very competitive with other institutions.  There is not much career placement support in place to assist with the job search and placement.

pros: A lot will depend on what department you are in but I've only had good experiences with mine. Great manager and coworkers make it a great place to work.
cons: I've not always been satisfied with the HR functions, sometimes the system seems too slow when changes take effect and each year I sign a new contract, there ends up being a gap in insurance or salary that takes multiple phone calls/emails to resolve.

pros: There are students and scholars that come make contributions in spite of the systemic waste.
cons: Bloated bureaucracy, wasteful spending, too many cowardly, overpaid provosts. There are a few programs that border on being pure diploma mills. There are more than a few people who solely exist to protect their status and position. My immediate supervisor insisted that reports be falsified to boost our statistics. There is always a push to try to spend your budget before the end of the fiscal year so that monies are not returned to the State coffers. This stubborn ignorance that causes people to refuse to return unused monies is draining our government. Liberal agenda is too often forced down your throat. Is happens in every department. Politics at its worst.

pros: Interesting work in the lab and field. My colleagues were a wonderful and diverse group of people. I continued on to graduate school, so the experience and contacts worked in my favor. I made friends, but there was no pressure to be best friends outside of work.
cons: Even though the work varied, the tasks were monotonous. It was an academic setting, so status was an issue. I started as a state employee, paying a low salary, but things changed when my status changed to federal employee.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great place to work with excellent t research environment and a state-of-the art library. Though it depends very much on the particular group that one is working with and the supervisor, I'm very happy with my adviser and the overall research opportunity. Besides, there are couple of really excellent courses that help in honing other skills besides being groomed as an expert in one's own research realm.
cons: There is not much scope of practical experiment in the field of wireless communication. The research is more on the theoretical side.

pros: Lots of great places to eat on campus. Gym membership. Cafeteria.
cons:
No raises unless you get a different position that isn't a lateral move. If it is the same salary grade you won't get a raise.
Management didn't question when employees leave. They were happy to see employees leave. No real advancement opportunities because they just want to see you leave. Management was condescending and insulting. Management doesn't understand why people stay & work there.
Low pay.
Few departments cross-train their staff.

pros: Loved working in Talley Student Union. Management was helpful and supportive of student employees. Was able do work on school work when not busy at the information desk. Environment was friendly and fun. I enjoyed going to work.
cons: Often poor communication between student staff members. Hard to find answers for guests because of coworkers lack of interest. It was a frustrating job when you couldn't answer a guest's question.

review_title: Any lab experience will vary, but don't expect any protection as a postdoc
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great for men!  And if you love the south, then this is absolutely the place for you
cons: NC State will protect PIs that behave inappropriately towards their subordinates.  If you have a great PI, it won't be an issue for you.  But NCSU really needs a changing of the guard

pros: The higher education environment is a wonderful thing to be part of.  There are lots of opportunities for training and learning if you seek them out.  The department you work in is what determines how your experience here will be.
cons: State employee benefits are not that great, I was surprised that benefits weren't better.  If you are a SPA employee, you are seen as not important.  I say that even though I'm EPA.  Some of the long-term employees are at a point where they need to retire and let the culture change.

review_title: A great place to do science.
job_title: Research Associate Post Doc in Kannapolis, NC
pros: Great environment, awesome staff. There are a lot of really smart people to interact with and to discuss one's research. The buildings are not only aesthetically pleasing, but contain top notch lab equipment and computer resources.
cons:
Job is grant-funded, i.e., temporary. There is no support for continued career opportunities, which makes the situation very frustrating: Nothing like having to apply for a job every year.
Paperwork. Lots of paperwork to get anything approved.

review_title: Nice University to Work for, but Terrible PI
pros: Good benefits and helpful employees, other than the professor I worked for.
cons: The only problem I had was the person that I directly worked for. Hard to get in touch with if there was a problem, no clear instructions given with projects, very unrealistic expectations on how long it takes to complete tasks, etc.

review_title: I enjoyed working at NC State
pros: I loved working for a University -- there is a great deal of energy and students. The benefits of working for the state are many -- health benefits are paid for by the state, and there is a good 401K match. There is also a good deal of vacation.
cons: Maternity leave is not paid for, and sometimes we did not get raises.

review_title: If you are not T/TT faculty, you don't want to work here.
pros: Can build great relationships with the faculty staff and have a decent work-life balance in most areas.  Campus is central to downtown, so there are great places for your morning coffee, lunch, or dinner if you have a late night.
cons: The business side of the University, where all the staff work, is getting very rough.  Continuous budget cuts are directly affecting staff reductions with less and less staff to do a growing amount of work.  Constantly having to do more with less is a very stressful place to be.

review_title: Love the Pack, but working here is hit or miss...
job_title: Technology Support Specialist in Raleigh, NC
pros: University environment is great, laid back atmosphere (sometimes), and lots of freedom to get involved in the things you're interested in - lots of campus opportunities.
cons: Depending on the unit you're in you may have it great or really not so great. Budget cuts have made some central units run bare-bones and it's hard to find opportunities to move up within the organization

review_title: NC State Univ - Great place to work for a grad student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Excellent group of professors, good access and availability to a wide range of instruments and facilities at the chemical engineering department
cons: Labs for chemical engineering are divided into multiple buildings but this only causes minor inconvenience. Food place on centennial campus is not great but hopefully in the future they will be more options.

pros: Great flexibility and autonomy.  If you're a faculty member, it's pretty good.  If you're a professional, non-faculty employee, it can also be good.  Lots of vacation time. I don't know about regular staff.
cons: Salary is below market.  Recognition of doing a good job is non existent.  Leadership from department to department is highly variable.  Some department/unit heads have no management training or experience.  This creates undesirable results

pros: Freedom while working, training at work and setting your own schedule. Also the environment is really nice. Lots of newer buildings and technologies. Good location in the Triangle.
cons: Student workers often get pretty low wages with no chance of a raise. There is also too much administration to deal with at times. This can often hinder the progress of work. Lack of support from management. They don't often reward hard work.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Graduate researchers directly report to their advising faculty. In most cases, the role calls for independent work with adviser playing roles of mentor and setting long term goals.
cons: Pay is obviously minimal and it is not adjusted for rate of inflation. Typically involves 60hr work weeks for 20hrs of pay. I must add; I am writing this review for access information on glassdoor.com. These work conditions are standard norms of graduate research and one should not pursue graduate research if you are not self-motivated to work hard and long hours with little financial compensation.

review_title: Grow Wherever You Want To Go
job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Raleigh, NC
pros: An institution with such a massive staff, faculty, and temporary worker population brings much room for growth and exposure. Lots of opportunities to learn, teach, participate, and get involved within the happenings and progress of NC State. You also can't beat state benefits and it's retirement program.
cons: Leadership is not timely in regards to notifying their teams of updates, memos, and policy changes. Pay will always be lower than private companies, with increases and bonuses more or less out of your hands as it's up to the Legislature each year.

review_title: Great experience and opportunity working with students
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Working with intelligent students was a delight. I learned so much from them. Shadowing some of the best professors in the industry was also very beneficial to my own professional development. Being a TA complimented my studies well. The paycheck and benefits were greatly appreciated. It never felt like I was going to work.
cons: Depending on which professor you were assigned to, workload, opportunity, and expectations could vary wildly. Sometimes last minute requests conflicted with my personal classwork, resulting in a quick scrambled to get everything done on time.

review_title: Great for faculty, terrible for staff.
pros: Decent pay.  No benefits unless full-time, and they keep changing those for full-time.
cons: Apathetic and complacent employees who hate their jobs.  Bureaucracy.  The faculty abuse the staff, and take credit for all their work.  Abuse of grant funds.  Over-spending.  No training.  Hardly any orientation, yet expected to know constantly changing standard operating procedures.  No SOP manual for employees.  Good Luck!  Tenure faculty tend to not do anything and cannot be fired, even when a conflict of interest in financial is present.

review_title: Ok, lots of red tape and bureaucracy though
job_title: Administrative Support Associate in Raleigh, NC
pros: The benefits are good and the university is large and interesting. I like the area and enjoy having the restaurants and cafeteria options for lunch.
cons: There is too much bureaucracy and red tape. Departments are isolationist and the pay is only so-so. Parking is terrible. It is not a very attractive university and the traffic is frustrating. Many of the buildings are old and need updated.

review_title: Worked at the Department of Computer Science as a TA for the algorithms course. Was a very fulfilling experience.
pros: Great place to work at. The Centennial campus is fantastic and the Hunt Library is a nice place to conduct office hours on certain days. Can engage in very interesting discussions with the students.
cons:
Not many.
Not allowed to bring personal computer during office hours.
Lack of a project in the course.

review_title: Every department has a different culture
pros: I worked for the Institute of Nonprofits that was just starting a program for nonprofit leaders. The group was friendly and genuinely interested in helping leaders. The participants were from all over the U.S. and adult learners.
cons: Faculty and staff has cruddy communication, and in turn, instructors had no idea of feedback and success of the courses they taught so you couldn't make corrections in real time. Also, instructors didn't know what was being taught/ covered in other sections or where the new program was headed for the future.

pros: Great salary and benefits (compared to other Higher Ed Institutions in the area), constant growth and change, lots of opportunities for advancement, promotion of sustainability
cons: Tend to promote from within (but not necessarily the right person, just best interviewee), statewide budget cuts have caused numerous reorganizations and position cuts, many silos, starting to do less with less

pros: Great Students and Co-Workers that are mission focused.  It is very rewarding to work to connect students and researchers with the tools they need to complete their education and realize ideas.  Good health benefits, safe work environment.
cons: Administration makes decisions outside of department feedback, and operational realities.  Decisions are made in ways that do not reflect the academic needs of the students.  Can be very siloed.

review_title: NC State is a very large institution with a huge variety of work experiences
pros: There are many opportunities at NC State, no matter your field or specialization.
cons: Because it is a state government institution, you may not be paid as much as in the private sector. Longevity is rewarded, however.

job_title: Operations and Systems Specialist in Raleigh, NC
pros: I worked at DELTA for a while, and I found it to be an excellent place to work, with excellent coworkers, a good product, and a good business plan.  The department head runs the department very well.  DELTA was a good, fun place to work.
cons: The only real con is that it is a state entity, but there are benefits to state employment too.  State employment means that directives from the NC legislature affect the employment situation.

review_title: Overall a great quality of life work environment
job_title: Information Technology Specialist in Raleigh, NC
pros: You will make more in private but the quality of life and work-life balance are great.  Can be a wonderful place to work.
cons: Insecure, negative people love to make others around them miserable. Often managers are peons with long titles beside their names.

review_title: Teaching Assistant at Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Due to poor supervision, there is room for being yourself and try different things that would be difficult at other universities.
cons: Teaching assistant are paid very poorly and have no absolutely no job security. Also, the department doesn't pursue a merit based hiring practice which makes TA very vulnerable. On top of that TA perks don't cover 1200 dollars a year required fees.

review_title: Good School - TA/RA-ships for not fully-funded programs suck
job_title: Graduate Teaching and Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: It's a good education that I'm sure will pay off, but as a master's student it costs a lot.
cons: TA or RA assistantships don't pay enough if you are in a program without a thesis (i.e. you don't go into the program with a "job" as a TA/RA, you pick up these jobs as you go through classes and profs like you). I was paid more working for the university library ($15/hour) than I was working as a  TA and RA (~9.50/hour).

review_title: Leading research university with opportunities for job growth and ties to local industry.
pros:
NC State is a top-20 ranked university that is able to attract talented students and faculty.
There are lots of available resources, including research facilities and funding opportunities. There are also ample professional development opportunities. The university community is supportive and Raleigh is an excellent location for young people or families.
cons: The salary and benefits may not be as competitive as the commercial sector. There are many opportunities for jobs in the region that would offer higher compensation.

job_title: Student IT Technical Associate in Raleigh, NC
pros: The hours are very flexible, the management is very accommodating. and the other students are great. The full-time staff is also relatively young, so it doesn't always seem like work.
cons: The ITECS Help Desk is only open 8-5, so classes often get in the way of work and vice versa. The weekly limit is also 20 hours for students, so you cannot work more than that.

review_title: For the most part the experience was good.
pros: Good benefit's, hour's are good, the area and people within community are mostly good
cons:
annual review's are not compencatied for good or very good in last 2 1/2 year's
manager's treat situation's differently.  Due to who you are and what the job title is.

pros: This place is an amazing combination of industry and academia. A class 1000 clean room shared by multiple companies and academic institutions in Research Triangle Park. One of the best advantages of working at NC Nanofabrication is that you'll have the chance to get trained one-on-one by staff members who have seen variety of work scenes previously.
cons: You will miss the huge group of co-workers and events you'll normally see in a bigger setting and company. Other than that there will be no disadvantage.

pros: very supportive environment.  I cant say that I was ever expected to take on more responsibility than I thought I could handle by myself.
cons: They do not support career advancement opportunities such as higher education or vocational certifications.  This is not expected from a university that prides itself in advancing its students.

pros: great opportunity to see what NC State is about .. also the food is good
cons: noticed that there was unprofessionalism ,  had a problem with one supervisor ... very rude and obnoxious behavior toward employees,    favoritism  is a main issue all employees should be treated with equality .

review_title: Good place for plant biology research
pros: This is a great place since there is a lot of opportunity to collaborate with other people in similar fields at UNC , Duke, and industry at RTP.  Additionally, NCSU has a wide variety of seminar that are offered.
cons: Parking is always an issue at any campus.  Each department is very independent on campus.  It would be nice to see more collaboration within NCSU.

pros: This institution is alright for work in the biology field. I make enough to take care of the essentials (rent, bills) and I get decent health insurance. Sometimes seminars are offered, but not to the extent of the academic neighbors in the triangle region (UNC-CH, Duke Univ.).
cons: Department politics are a bit dodgy. Genetics, Toxicology, and Microbiology have been combined to form an umbrella-esque biology department. Nothing really seems to have changed though.

review_title: I worked at North Carolina State University for several years.
pros:
A (mostly) laid back work environment filled with friendly, supportive coworkers.
Respectable compensation, with good vacation benefits.
The location in Raleigh offers a good variety of activities.
cons:
Budget cuts over the last few years have severely affected some units, with little prospect for improvement in the near future.
Few, if any, raises due to the budget cuts.
Upper management of some units are disconnected and opaque at best, and rarely provide communication.

pros: I really enjoy working for North Carolina State University as a teaching assistant because the hours are slow, but constant. Also it's really nice that you get a raise every semester
cons: The only downside is that there are a not a lot of hours per week. Also, the pay grade is low at first, but raises do occur every semester.

review_title: Nice Place to Work but could use improvement.
job_title: Administrative Support Specialist in Raleigh, NC
pros: Time off for Christmas break.
cons: Not much time off, no personal days, non-exempt employees will soon have to clock in/out. Very difficult to move around and advance within the University. Not many opportunities to move up the ladder. No raises or bonuses.. but that's the state. Very political, low morale, not much in the way of employee incentives. More focuses on research, students and faculty.

review_title: Professional environment. Good communications, reasonable balance between expectations and goals.
pros: Professional, personable colleagues. Good collaboration and communication. Good office condidtions. Clear goals and expectations. Reasonable work and life balance, flexilbity when needed.
cons: Parking can be difficult. Actively need to work to meet colleagues in other areas. Overall business process run well, change is difficulty and process is lengthy.

review_title: Great opportunities for students through assistantships
pros: Given the enormous breadth in areas of research, NCSU provides great opportunities for student research assistants, both graduate and undergraduate. I worked on a short research contract to provide software for a lab. It was interesting experience working with a number of departments.
cons: Given the short term of my contract, I would have hoped for a little more guidance from the principle investigators.

pros: Has great programs, dedicated staff.
cons: No job security - annual renewal of the contract for a full time faculty. Contract faculty is unable to use the vacation time to its fullest.  No promotions of any kind: you are paid the same despite years of experience in your subject and with Masters as a person with an Associate Degree teaching the same course with 1 year experience.  It must be different if one is not under an annual contract. Sad comparisons - it seems the laws to not apply to the State of North Carolina as they would in other states.

review_title: Grad student teaching assistant at North Carolina State University
pros: NCSU is huge and offers a lot of opportunities. It also has a lot of connections to the real world, and I've heard that job placement is good. I appreciate how flexible my program is with its class offerings and qualifying exams. They seem realistic too, in terms of having a balance between a personal life and academics.
cons: I have a small salary, which makes finances tight, but that's typical of being a teacher's assistant.

review_title: Good benefits for a fun job!
job_title: Administrative Support Specialist in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great co-workers, beautiful campus, good educational benefits, access to professional development opportunities, Chancellor recently announced endowment for children of faculty and staff to receive scholarships.
cons: Not enough funding, upper administration doesn't seem connected to what students need, upper administration gets paid a LOT while lower level employees struggle for raises.

pros: Good work environment if you get into the right lab. Good health care. Good public transit to work and a lot of nearby attractions.
cons: Program is too long and you don't learn much after your second year. Low standards and a LOT of incompetent people. Pay is way too low and in 5 years they've never given anyone a raise. Expect to work 60+ hours a week and still be told you need to work more hours.

review_title: I enjoyed all the opportunities I gained working at NC State! Different experiences working for URec and Women's Center!
pros: You get to work with your peers, create relationships with faculty and staff and you can work around your schedule to make things easier for yourself while in school
cons:
Sometimes to difficult to move up in position 
Pay can be little to nothing at times
Can only work up to 20 hours and that can be hard for some people because everyone's financial situation is different.

pros: Good work environment and friendly management.  Nice campus and the students are friendly.  I never had any problems with any of the facilities.
cons: The pay is not entirely competitive.  There is also not enough time off each year.  The student environment, while fun, does get old after a while.

pros: We have been working with PeopleSoft for 20 years and have a very experienced team of analysts that make implementations, upgrades, and production support interesting and fun
cons: We fall further and further behind total compensation in the private sector because our pay increases are determined by the state's legislature.

review_title: Difficult to get use to if you mostly worked for the private sector.
pros: If you are able to stay for a long period of time, you have health benefits and a pension after you retire.
cons: Salaries are lower than private sector overall.  Management writes job specs for people they want versus writing job specs for the best available person.  Very political landscape.  Everyone is trying to grab turf and keep it.

pros: Interacting with students and exposing them to different career fields. The university has an excellent office of faculty development that help faculty improve upon teaching effectiveness and help you publish those techniques.
cons: No department head or dean will ever tell you straight what how many classes taught make up your teaching component. They no longer give 12 month appointments but have an expectation of you being in the office 12 months a year. Consequently you obtain zero vacation or sick leave.

pros: A lot of great people, diverse work, and "bleeding edge" technology.  Take what you can from the experience while you're still sane because it won't last long. The stereotypical "state" employee mentality takes over, and soon you're just there for a check.
cons: Some really really horrible people. Uneducated, illiterate, and antisocial people get promoted in this community.  The management is a vacuum of ideas.  The management is also antiquated.  They allow for the stealing of ideas.

pros: Great opportunity for students who have a good understanding of organic chemistry to teach others in the entry-level organic chemistry series.  Job fits with students' schedules, and it also helps to reinforce those concepts that you've learned and expound on them.
cons: Pay could definitely be a little better, although any income as a student is nice.  Lack of oversight may be an issue for those who aren't fully ready to teach in a lab environment.

job_title: PhD Student, Graduate Research Assistant, Teaching Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros:
You have great and nice people around who will give you useful advice, instructions and help. 
when  you have paper work to file, they work out very efficiently.
cons: less activities on campus, not very much workshops or seminars for you to learn and communicate with people from different disciplines. no gym on the new campus.

review_title: Awesome work environment, always loved my coworkers
pros: I was a student worker who worked as a Community Assistant and was promoted to Community Assistant Coordinator. Looking back, that was the most satisfied I have ever been with a job. Great boss, no drama, and truly enjoyed the job.
cons: Creating employee schedules was the worst part just because of everyone's class schedules. It was a minor bump in the road. My workers were always happy to help out however they could.

job_title: Laboratory Teaching Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Make your own hours, close work with a professor, rewarding work with students in a field you are knowledgeable in.
cons: some students can be demanding, but that comes with the position and should be expected when working with any group of people.

pros: All the senior staff is very welcoming and Its a healthy work Environment. You get to be around sports and that brings in positive energy in You.
cons: Actually None. For the amount of job that you are given pay is satisfactory and you get promoted if you do a good job.

pros: A lot of seriously smart, motivated people attacking the problems facing the people of North Carolina and the world. Talented folks who are committed to innovative research that doesn’t come at the expense of their compassion.
cons: Salary caps and hiring freezes are a fact of life for any state funded institution, NCSU is no exception.

job_title: Administrative Support Specialist in Raleigh, NC
pros:
-Work/life balance is great.
-Great benefits beyond your basic benefits (i.e. tuition waivers, acess to tons of NCSU centric events, etc.) 
-People that work here are (mostly) great and down to earth.
-There is room for advancement if you work for it.
-Overall, I have been happier here than I have been at any other company.
cons: -State employees don't always get the greatest pay, etc. but this is across the board. The benefits outweigh the lower pay.

pros: Tuition is paid in full as a teaching assistant.  Salary isn't a lot but it is enough.  Flexible working hours.
cons: Can't really say that I have any cons.  As a teaching assistant, much of your experience is going to be based on what class and professor you are assigned to.

pros: There is great opportunity for leadership experience while earning a little bit of extra money.  There is great interaction with students and administration
cons: There are a lot of other people there.  There is a lot of competition especially in this tough economical time.

job_title: Communications and External Relations in Raleigh, NC
pros: If your willing to change units, there are always job growth opportunities.
cons: Salary is the lowest across the country. You have to pay to park. Technology is minimal. There is a large number of employees under qualified but have been there for 20 to 30 years. People tend to hire friends and family members.

pros: nice people, comfortable environment (living, studying and working), less expensive, close to RTP area, and more waiting for you to find...
cons: I can not think many cons now. the only thing I wanna mention is that you'd better have a car to live here since it's relatively small.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Work-life balance as a graduate student is very flexible and is largely dictate by the advisor's personality and work schedule.  In my case, my advisor was very hands off and did not require strict hours so long as I produce results in a timely manner.
cons: Work can be tedious and time consuming.  And often overtime (50+ hours/week) is required to obtain results.  Given the level of compensation, this seems a bit extreme.

review_title: Innovative leadership is right around the corner, as soon as some old-timers retire.
pros: The University has great academic programs and research. The School of Textiles is unbelievable. Centennial Campus will become a hotspot for technology and biotech development in next ten years. Most employees are super friendly.
cons: Militaristic management structure which is unwilling to accept ideas from "outsiders." Pay is surprisingly low compared to other areas of the country and the benefits are laughingly bad.

pros:
Employees (and students!) are quite willing to help and collaborate when needed. I actually never encountered a staff member or faculty member that I didn't enjoy speaking with and/or working with.

The campus is gorgeous and fun to traverse (despite being so large). Raleigh is also a great tight-knit city.
cons: It was only a part-time job and there was no real option to move into a full-time position (not that I expected there to be).

pros: Lovely folks to work with.  Great caseload (medical and interventional).  Raleigh is a great city to live in as well.  Clients from all over NC
cons: Long hours, low pay for residents.  No dental insurance and no raises for 3 years.  Little time off for study.

pros: Exposed to interesting subject matter; nice, friendly colleagues; good place to get experience for technology transfer or intellectual property experience
cons: Low level of responsibilities; no room for growth; though office setup is interesting, coming in every day could be pretty boring

pros:
The hours are very flexible each week.
The job takes place on campus so it is easy to do/commute to.
cons: There is definitely micro-management since you must meet with supervisor several times a semester. In addition, you must take a one-credit hour class.

review_title: Project Manager at Top-notch University in Facilities Management
job_title: Project Manager/Engineering Technician in Raleigh, NC
pros: Good Benefits, good hours, good work-life balance, apart of a large system, State employee retirement. Feel a part of the family and team.
cons: Pay to park, departments managers are penny pinchers, commute, and no formal training for new employees. They kind of throw you out on your own.

review_title: Great place to study and work
pros: Good pay. Covers tuition fee. Facilities are great. It has a really large gym. Faculty are good and helpful. Nice place to learn. Transport facilities are excellent.
cons: CS department is not one of the top departments in this category. Difficult to get funding unless one plans to do PhD.

pros: Great University! The work is not hard or strenuous and you can pretty much make up your own hours.You get the opportunity to collaborate with other researchers and you learn a whole lot!
cons: If you're a temporary worker you don't get paid for the times that you are out of work. There's not an opportunity to move up and advance and the pay is not very good.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Undergraduate research is exciting, you get to work with cool people, and learn more about what kinds of topics are getting funding
cons: Entirely dependent on your advisor. Mine was cool and the work was interesting, but that might not be the case for others. Also the time keeping software is a wee bit outdated

review_title: Good place to gain practical work experience for Masters students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros:
-Fair compensation provided. It is good enough for a single person to rent an apartment and live off-campus.
- The Professors are friendly and approachable. Great research and industry projects.
cons: - Funding is not always available and also contingent on a professor taking up industry projects. So unless you are a Ph.D. student, the opportunities to get a stipend and fee waiver for Masters students are few.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Nice people. Nice research. Excellent facilities. The laboratories are really great and awesome place for research related activities. Professors are very helpful. Great place for international graduates.
cons: The parking permit cost is very high. The bus service to school specially at night is not very good. Also, in recent years there had been a safety concern at various places specially at night time.

review_title: Research Assistant in ECE department at NC State
pros: The university provides students much resource such as textbooks, computers, chances to talk to people such as research faculty and people from the industry.
cons: The university is a relatively more flexible environment. Sometimes activities, transactions, or research-related purchases are not organized or responsive enough for students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Extremely organized administrative staff and campus environment. Numerous opportunities for personal and professional growth provided on campus.
cons: Personalities of individual faculty members often class and can result in a large degree of "politicking" at the expense of students and graduate students. Your long term success is extremely dependent on the outlook of your graduate mentor with very little control provided by administration or graduate programs director. Fairly standard for graduate school though.

job_title: Student Graphic Designer in Raleigh, NC
pros: Working as a Student Graphic Designer at NC State is wonderful because the other employees and people in management are very friendly. They are very understanding about having flexible hours for students.
cons: The payment does not change and you can not work more than 20 hours a week.

review_title: I got the job and still love it a year later!
pros: Why do I love my job?  I'm able to use my creative skills, given opportunities to think outside of the box, love my supervisor and my co-workers.  The benefits are great...compared to my old job where I had no benefits.
cons: Politics...NC Politics, their decisions effect everyone state wide.  The good and bad decisions.

pros: Good work life balance. Nice working environment. Nice weather in North Carolina. Good opportunity for student who want to go a long way either in industry or academia.
cons: No clear career plan for Ph.D. student. Chemical engineering department does not have many affiliation with companies. Those who want to pursue a career in industry have to submit resumes online like others.

pros: The other students who work with you are some of the best people you'll get to meet. The schedules are flexible(-ish) and the pay is comparatively pretty great to other places.
cons: The upper management can come off as abrasive or intimidating, especially to newer employees. The 20-hour rule is frustrating, as well, but I understand the reasoning behind including it.

pros: Plenty of room to learn and grow in the position, with lots of exposure to the research project going on around the lab.
cons: As a student, it can be hard to find convenient times with the researchers to cross train and to help with projects.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Excellent work environment, sitting at a desk can be tiresome at times, but as a Library Assistant I come in contact with so many great people, that always stop by the desk to have a short conversation. The hours are great 8am-5pm Mon-Fri
cons: The pay is low.  On slow days and school holidays I still have to work and it gets rather boring with most people out of the office.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Many different mentors in various areas of knowledge
Communication between departments and collaboration for research projects is outstanding
Great departmental fellowship
Easy commute from anywhere in Raleigh
As a grad student, you get out of the experience exactly what you put in
cons:
Parking, the permit prices are outrageous and you still have to walk a mile to your destination
Accessibility to drive through campus, the block on Dan Allen Dr. is annoying
No cons dealing with academia

review_title: College of Textiles Underpays and Keeps Employees in the Dark
pros: fairly reasonable work/life balance, wide variety of research areas
cons: funding is low compared to other departments, refuse to announce assistantships and accompanying tuition remission until one week before classes start which is after tuition is due

pros: Can be convenient to work on campus. Close proximity. I imagine more flexibility in hours than an off campus job.
cons: Can feel exploiting at times. Highly unorganized. Superiors can be difficult to deal with and set in their ways.  Slow to implement useful change.

job_title: Sales And Events Coordinator in Raleigh, NC
pros: You get all your holidays and 2 weeks of vacation per year. Weekends are not terribly busy considering the hospitality position, and summers are very slow. Influx of fresh student energy every semester, and management works well with maintaining a good work life balance for this position in particular.
cons: HR, inner department politics, getting anything changed can be difficult with many hoops, and appreciation for your work is low.

review_title: Great Place to go to Graduate School
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Interesting work, Diverse departmental interests, Great education from experts in the field, ability to set your own hours, if you find a project you like it's about like a regular job
cons: Low pay, long hours, it's graduate school, lots of hoops to jump through, if you pick the wrong advisor you could be in for the long haul, tough finding employment even after an advanced degree

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: It is located in a beatiful city, I worked as a research assistant, the professors and HR are good. They provide you the insurance.
cons: Maybe sometimes, you need to do experiment, you need to make an apointments or wait for some time until the equipement has been repaired.

review_title: Good place, but could be better
pros: NCSU has a nice campus. It is comfortable to work as a graduate student  here. The school is also well-know for its engineering departments.
cons: Sometimes limited resources as a research graduate students. Some talent people (professors) in engineering departments are no longer attracted by the school in some cases... This could hurt the future reputation of its engineering departments.

job_title: Business and Technology Applications Analyst in Raleigh, NC
pros: Relaxed atmosphere, college campus, solid campus community, free tickets to select athletic events, nice location, and fairly diverse population.
cons: Low salaries compared to private sector (particularly for staff), inconsistent salaries department to department, you have to pay for parking, low career advancement ceiling, mediocre benefits as state employees.

pros: Great for temporary work. Very flexible. I would recommend working with an entomology lab if you want to get some research experience.
cons: Be sure you know what you're getting into when you agree to work as a part time temporary employee: low pay, 0 advancement opportunity depending on the lab. They'll put you to work and give as little as possible in return.

job_title: Business and Technology Analyst in Raleigh, NC
pros: Great systems to work on and improve - great sense of pride in the University.
cons: Tight "good ole boy network" that doesn't always accept outsiders.  Unprofessional in terms of people gossiping.  The University is large, so this comment will certainly not fit all Divisions!

review_title: Very supportive staff and people. Everyone is wishing for each one's success
pros:
Very friendly staff. Lots of interaction among peers and friendly atmosphere.  Health insurance is part of postdoc employment.
Campus rent is great. Lots of lakes around campus. Campus location, trees and climate is great.
cons: The campus has buildings at different zones. You might have need to drive for meetings, seminars and or instrument usage.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros: lots of opportunities, very friendly and extremely well qualified professors..
cons: a little on the lower side on the stipends of the TA's and RA's..also it takes a lot of time to get an advisor (2 semesters on an average).

pros: Good environment. All people here, including professor and students are very kind. The whole university has a uniform campus value.
cons: Traffic for students is not good enough. People that don't drive own car will become inconvenience during night and weekend.

pros:
Good Retirement Plan
Excellent Work Hours
I was not micromanaged I was given freedom to lead my area. 
Support for continuing education.
cons:
Dependent on State Legislature for raises
Bureaucratic outdate processes that cause more time that benefit
To difficult to get rid of employees that should not be employed.

review_title: People here are nice. Pay is reasonable considering the low living expense in Raleigh
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros:
It is a comprehensive university, you can meet all kinds of people.
Raleigh is a good place to live if you like nice people and good environment over big cities.
cons: The pay is only around or below average.

pros: This program is very organized and teaches all of the skills needed to begin a career in data science.  99% job placement by graduation.  Industry experts as teachers.  Access to industry standard tools.  Overall, a great program at a great price.  Well worth the investment.
cons: None! Everything they do is geared towards success!

review_title: I've been doing web development for NC State for several years.
pros: Good work environment, knowledgeable peers, nice benefits, relaxed atmosphere, relatively low pressure, time off scales with how long you've been here
cons: raises are few and far between, little room for growth, innovation tends to stagnate, staff sometimes overburdened

pros: The environment in Raleigh is very good and the school is excellent at engineering. People there are very friendly to me.
cons: Some management is not very good, some staff do a little things, although I believe most of them have responsibility.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Raleigh, NC
pros:
people are friendly,
weather is so nice
lots of local job opportunities
cons: Even through NC States on average has better engineering departments than its neighbor schools like Duke and UNC, but it is often over shadowed by the two.

job_title: Software License Consultant in Raleigh, NC
